Pico Projector Development Kit

Congratulations on your new DLP Pico Projector Development Kit. This is where you can find some demos to try it out with your BeagleBoard.

Initializing an SD card from a Linux host

You'll need a 2GB or greater SD card and an adapter that works with your Linux host to configure Linux on your BeagleBoard.

If you already have a Linux host

  1. Format the SD card, two alternatives.
    • Gparted method
    • Fdisk method
  2. Download the two SD partition images.
    • pico_sd_fat.tar.bz2.
    • pico_sd_ext3.tar.bz2.
  3. With the SD formatted and mounted on your Linux host, extract the partition images to the SD card.  Assumes you're in the directory where the image files reside otherwise type the full path of the image file.  Replace /media/beagle_fat with your SD fat partition mount point, same for /media/beagle_ext3.
    • sudo tar xvjf pico_sd_fat.tar.bz2 -C /media/beagle_fat
    • sudo tar xvjf pico_sd_ext3.tar.bz2 -C /media/beagle_ext3

<font size="5">If you don't have a Linux host</font>

Using 'dd' from any operating system

A 'dd' image can be created from Linux without access to an SD card, then written from any operating system where 'dd' can be run.

  1. Build the image using mkpicoimg.sh adjusting as necessary for the size of your SD card, location of your files, etc. --- or ---
  2. Simply download pico.img.gz.
  3. gzcat sd.img.gz | dd of= your device
